1using System;
2using System.Collections.Generic;
3​
4namespace TechnicalIndicators
5{
6 /// <summary>
7 /// Historical Volatility (HV)
8 /// </summary>
9 /// <remarks>
10 /// Measures the dispersion of returns over time, annualized.
11 /// <list type="bullet">
12 /// <item><description>Uses Log Returns: ln(Close / PrevClose)</description></item>
13 /// <item><description>Calculates Standard Deviation of Log Returns.</description></item>
14 /// <item><description>Annualizes by multiplying by Sqrt(252) (trading days).</description></item>
15 /// </list>
16 /// </remarks>
17 public class HistoricalVolatility
18 {
19 public int Period { get; }
20 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
21​
22 public HistoricalVolatility(int period = 20)
23 {
24 Period = period;
25 }
26​
27 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
28 {
29 Values.Clear();
30 var c = new List<CandleData>(candles);
31 if (c.Count == 0) return;
32​
33 // Step 1: Calculate Log Returns
34 var logReturns = new List<double> { 0 };
35 for (int i = 1; i < c.Count; i++)
36 {
37 double close = (double)c[i].Close;
38 double prevClose = (double)c[i - 1].Close;
39 // Log Return = ln(P_t / P_t-1)
40 logReturns.Add(prevClose > 0 ? Math.Log(close / prevClose) : 0);
41 }
42​
43 // Step 2: Rolling Standard Deviation
44 for (int i = 0; i < c.Count; i++)
45 {
46 if (i < Period) { Values.Add(null); continue; }
47​
48 double sum = 0;
49 for (int j = 0; j < Period; j++) sum += logReturns[i - j];
50 double mean = sum / Period;
51​
52 double sumSq = 0;
53 for (int j = 0; j < Period; j++)
54 {
55 double d = logReturns[i - j] - mean;
56 sumSq += d * d;
57 }
58​
59 // Sample Standard Deviation
60 double stdDev = Math.Sqrt(sumSq / (Period - 1));
61​
62 // Step 3: Annualize (assuming daily data, 252 days)
63 Values.Add((decimal)(stdDev * Math.Sqrt(252) * 100));
64 }
65 }
66​
67 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period = 20)
68 {
69 var hv = new HistoricalVolatility(period);
70 hv.Calculate(candles);
71 return hv.Values;
72 }
73 }
74}

1// =============================================================================
2// Logic Breakdown (HistoricalVolatility)
3// =============================================================================
4//
5// This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6// Historical Volatility (HV) technical indicator.
7// We explain *why* code is written this way and *how* data transforms
8// line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
9//
10// [Core Concepts]
11//
12// 1. What is Historical Volatility?
13// [Why] Volatility measures how much prices "swing" over time.
14// High volatility = risky; Low volatility = stable.
15// [What] HV calculates the standard deviation of log returns,
16// then annualizes it to express as a yearly percentage figure.
17// [Use] Options pricing, risk management, position sizing.
18//
19// 2. Log Returns (Continuous Compounding)
20// [Formula] LogReturn[i] = ln(Close[i] / Close[i-1])
21// [Why] Log returns are additive (good for statistics).
22// Regular returns are not additive over time.
23//
24// 3. Standard Deviation
25// [Formula] σ = sqrt( Σ(x - mean)^2 / (n-1) )
26// [Why] Measures "spread" or dispersion of returns around the mean.
27// We use (n-1) for "sample" standard deviation (Bessel's correction).
28//
29// 4. Annualization Factor
30// [Formula] HV = σ * √252 * 100
31// [Why] 252 = approximate trading days per year.
32// Multiply by 100 to express as a percentage.
33// [Example] σ = 0.01 per day -> HV = 0.01 * 15.87 * 100 ≈ 15.87%
34//
35// [Visual Plan]
36//
37// Day | Close | LogReturn
38// ----|-------|----------
39// 0 | 100 | - (No previous close)
40// 1 | 102 | ln(102/100) = 0.0198
41// 2 | 99 | ln(99/102) = -0.0299
42// ...
43//
44// StdDev of LogReturns over Period -> Annualize -> HV%
45//
46// =============================================================================
47​
48using System;
49using System.Collections.Generic;
50​
51namespace TechnicalIndicators
52{
53 // =============================================================================
54 // Logic Explanation: OHLCV Data Container
55 // =============================================================================
56 public readonly record struct CandleData(DateTime Timestamp, decimal Open, decimal High, decimal Low, decimal Close, long Volume);
57​
58 // =============================================================================
59 // Logic Explanation: Historical Volatility Class
60 // =============================================================================
61 public class HistoricalVolatility
62 {
63 // -------------------------------------------------------------
64 // Logic Explanation: Configuration
65 // -------------------------------------------------------------
66 public int Period { get; }
67 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
68​
69 // =============================================================================
70 // Logic Explanation: Constructor
71 // =============================================================================
72 public HistoricalVolatility(int period = 20)
73 {
74 // [Validation] Period must be positive.
75 if (period <= 0)
76 throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException(nameof(period));
77
78 Period = period;
79 }
80​
81 // =============================================================================
82 // Logic Explanation: Main Calculation Method
83 // =============================================================================
84 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
85 {
86 // -------------------------------------------------------------
87 // Step 1: Cleanup & Setup
88 // -------------------------------------------------------------
89 Values.Clear();
90 var c = new List<CandleData>(candles);
91 if (c.Count == 0) return;
92​
93 // -------------------------------------------------------------
94 // Step 2: Pre-calculate Log Returns
95 //
96 // [Why] We need log returns for each day to compute volatility.
97 // We store them in a list for efficient lookups later.
98 //
99 // [Visual: Log Return Calculation]
100 //
101 // Day 0: No previous close -> LogReturn = 0 (placeholder)
102 // Day 1: LogReturn = ln(Close[1] / Close[0])
103 // Day 2: LogReturn = ln(Close[2] / Close[1])
104 // ...
105 // -------------------------------------------------------------
106 var logReturns = new List<double> { 0 }; // Day 0 has no return
107​
108 for (int i = 1; i < c.Count; i++)
109 {
110 double close = (double)c[i].Close;
111 double prevClose = (double)c[i - 1].Close;
112​
113 // [Edge Case] Prevent division by zero or log of zero
114 if (prevClose > 0)
115 {
116 logReturns.Add(Math.Log(close / prevClose));
117 }
118 else
119 {
120 logReturns.Add(0);
121 }
122 }
123​
124 // -------------------------------------------------------------
125 // Step 3: Main Loop - Calculate Rolling Standard Deviation
126 //
127 // [Why] We need 'Period' log returns to compute volatility.
128 // Start outputting from index 'Period' (0-indexed).
129 // -------------------------------------------------------------
130 for (int i = 0; i < c.Count; i++)
131 {
132 // [Check] We need at least 'Period' returns for meaningful statistics.
133 // Since logReturns[0] is a placeholder, we need i >= Period.
134 if (i < Period)
135 {
136 Values.Add(null);
137 continue;
138 }
139​
140 // -------------------------------------------------------------
141 // Step 3a: Calculate Mean of Log Returns in Window
142 //
143 // [Visual: Window]
144 // logReturns: [..., R_{i-Period+1}, ..., R_i]
145 // ↑─────── Window ───────↑
146 // -------------------------------------------------------------
147 double sum = 0;
148 for (int j = 0; j < Period; j++)
149 {
150 sum += logReturns[i - j];
151 }
152 double mean = sum / Period;
153​
154 // -------------------------------------------------------------
155 // Step 3b: Calculate Sum of Squared Deviations
156 //
157 // [Formula] Σ(x - mean)^2
158 // [Why] This measures how "spread out" returns are.
159 // -------------------------------------------------------------
160 double sumSq = 0;
161 for (int j = 0; j < Period; j++)
162 {
163 double deviation = logReturns[i - j] - mean;
164 sumSq += deviation * deviation;
165 }
166​
167 // -------------------------------------------------------------
168 // Step 3c: Calculate Sample Standard Deviation
169 //
170 // [Formula] σ = sqrt(sumSq / (n - 1))
171 // [Why] Using (n-1) instead of n gives an unbiased estimate
172 // for sample data (Bessel's correction).
173 // -------------------------------------------------------------
174 double stdDev = Math.Sqrt(sumSq / (Period - 1));
175​
176 // -------------------------------------------------------------
177 // Step 3d: Annualize the Volatility
178 //
179 // [Formula] HV = σ * √252 * 100
180 // [Why] √252 scales daily volatility to annual.
181 // × 100 converts to percentage.
182 // -------------------------------------------------------------
183 double annualizedHV = stdDev * Math.Sqrt(252) * 100;
184​
185 Values.Add((decimal)annualizedHV);
186 }
187 }
188​
189 // =============================================================================
190 // Logic Explanation: Static Convenience Wrapper
191 //
192 // [IPO Block]
193 // Input: IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period
194 // Process: Creates instance, runs Calculate()
195 // Output: List of Historical Volatility values (in %)
196 // =============================================================================
197 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period = 20)
198 {
199 var hv = new HistoricalVolatility(period);
200 hv.Calculate(candles);
201 return hv.Values;
202 }
203 }
204}

1import math
2​
3class HistoricalVolatility:
4 """
5 Historical Volatility
6 Annualized Standard Deviation of Log Returns.
7 """
8 def __init__(self, period=20):
9 self.period = period
10 self.values = []
11​
12 def calculate(self, candles):
13 self.values.clear()
14 if len(candles) == 0: return
15​
16 # 1. Log Returns
17 log_returns = [0.0]
18 for i in range(1, len(candles)):
19 close = float(candles[i]['close'])
20 prev = float(candles[i-1]['close'])
21 if prev > 0:
22 log_returns.append(math.log(close / prev))
23 else:
24 log_returns.append(0.0)
25​
26 # 2. Rolling StdDev
27 for i in range(len(candles)):
28 if i < self.period:
29 self.values.append(None)
30 continue
31
32 # Subset of returns
33 subset = log_returns[i-self.period+1 : i+1]
34 # Note: C# code loops `for (int j = 0; j < Period; j++) sum += logReturns[i - j];`
35 # This is indices i, i-1, ... i-Period+1.
36 # Python slice [i-Period+1 : i+1] covers same range.
37
38 mean = sum(subset) / self.period
39 sum_sq = sum((r - mean)**2 for r in subset)
40
41 std_dev = math.sqrt(sum_sq / (self.period - 1))
42
43 # 3. Annualize
44 val = std_dev * math.sqrt(252) * 100
45 self.values.append(val)
46​
47def calculate(candles, period=20):
48 hv = HistoricalVolatility(period)
49 hv.calculate(candles)
50 return hv.values

1# =============================================================================
2# Logic Breakdown (Historical Volatility)
3# =============================================================================
4#
5# This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of
6# Historical Volatility (HV). We explain *why* code is written this way
7# and *how* data transforms line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
8#
9# [Core Concepts]
10# 1. Log Returns
11# Finance uses Natural Logarithm returns instead of Percentage change.
12# LogReturn = ln(Price_Today / Price_Yesterday)
13# [Why]
14# - Time Additivity: Log returns over multiple days can simply be summed.
15# - Normal Distribution: Log returns tend to follow a bell curve better
16# than simple % changes (which are bounded by -100%).
17#
18# 2. Volatility = Risk
19# We measure risk by calculating the Standard Deviation of these returns.
20# - High StdDev = Wild swings (Risky).
21# - Low StdDev = Flat movement (Safe).
22#
23# 3. Annualization
24# Volatility is standardly quoted as an "Annualized" number (e.g., 20%).
25# To convert Daily Volatility to Annual, we multiply by SQRT(TradingDays).
26# - Standard Trading Days = 252 (approx).
27# - AnnualVol = DailyVol * Sqrt(252).
28#
29# =============================================================================
30​
31import math
32​
33# -------------------------------------------------------------
34# Type-Level Explanation: HistoricalVolatility (class)
35#
36# [Why] Stateful. Tracks lookback period.
37# [What] Statistical measure of past price changes.
38# [How] Computes the annualized standard deviation of logarithmic returns over a specified lookback period to measure price volatility.
39# [Who] Options Traders, Risk Managers.
40# [Where] Heap.
41# -------------------------------------------------------------
42class HistoricalVolatility:
43​
44 # -------------------------------------------------------------
45 # Logic Explanation: Indicator Configuration (Public Properties)
46 #
47 # [Why]
48 # Allow specification of the measurement window.
49 # Standard is 20 days (approx 1 trading month) or 10 days.
50 # -------------------------------------------------------------
51​
52 # -------------------------------------------------------------
53 # Constructor: __init__
54 #
55 # [Input]
56 # - period: int (Window size)
57 #
58 # [Why]
59 # Initialize implementation constants.
60 # -------------------------------------------------------------
61 def __init__(self, period=20):
62
63 # -------------------------------------------------------------
64 # Logic Step 1: Validation
65 # -------------------------------------------------------------
66 if period <= 1:
67 raise ValueError(f"Period must be greater than 1. Received: {period}")
68​
69 self.period = period
70 self.values = []
71​
72​
73 # =============================================================================
74 # IPO: calculate
75 # =============================================================================
76 #
77 # [Input]
78 # - candles: list[dict] (Must contain 'close')
79 #
80 # [Process]
81 # 1. Pre-calculate Log Returns for the entire series.
82 # 2. Iterate with a sliding window.
83 # 3. Compute Standard Deviation of Log Returns in window.
84 # 4. Multiply by Sqrt(252) * 100 for Annual % scaling.
85 #
86 # [Output]
87 # - None (populates self.values)
88 # =============================================================================
89 def calculate(self, candles):
90
91 # -------------------------------------------------------------
92 # Logic Step 1: Reset
93 # -------------------------------------------------------------
94 self.values.clear()
95 count = len(candles)
96
97 if count == 0:
98 return
99​
100 # -------------------------------------------------------------
101 # Logic Step 2: Compute Log Returns (Pre-Pass)
102 #
103 # [Why]
104 # We need the daily change metric before we can calculate variance.
105 #
106 # [Formula]
107 # R = ln(Close / PrevClose)
108 #
109 # [Visual]
110 # Prices: [100, 105, 102]
111 # Returns: [0, 0.048, -0.029]
112 # -------------------------------------------------------------
113 log_returns = [0.0] * count # Pre-allocate size
114
115 # Start from index 1 (requires previous bar)
116 for i in range(1, count):
117 current = candles[i]['close']
118 prev = candles[i - 1]['close']
119
120 # Logic Step 2.1: Division Guard
121 # [Decision] Is prev price valid?
122 if prev > 0 and current > 0:
123 log_returns[i] = math.log(current / prev)
124 else:
125 log_returns[i] = 0.0
126​
127 # -------------------------------------------------------------
128 # Logic Step 3: Rolling Standard Deviation
129 #
130 # [Why]
131 # StdDev is the root of Variance.
132 # Variance is the average of squared differences from the Mean.
133 # -------------------------------------------------------------
134
135 # Optimization Constant: Sqrt(252) * 100
136 # 252 is standard trading days in a year.
137 # 100 converts decimal (0.2) to percent (20.0).
138 annual_factor = math.sqrt(252) * 100.0
139​
140 for i in range(count):
141
142 # -------------------------------------------------------------
143 # Logic Step 3.1: Insufficient Data
144 #
145 # [Decision]
146 # Do we have 'period' number of returns (including current)?
147 # Note: Returns start valid at index 1.
148 # So window [i-period+1 ... i] must be valid.
149 # -------------------------------------------------------------
150 if i < self.period:
151 self.values.append(None)
152 continue
153​
154 # -------------------------------------------------------------
155 # Logic Step 3.2: Window Analysis
156 #
157 # Compute Mean and SumSqDiff.
158 # Implementation Note: Simple loose loop for clarity O(N*P).
159 # -------------------------------------------------------------
160
161 # A. Calculate Mean of Returns
162 sum_returns = 0.0
163 # From (i - period + 1) to (i)
164 # Actually, standard HV often excludes the very first return of the window
165 # if we are being strict about "Price Windows", but usually
166 # we just take the last N returns.
167 # Let's use the returns at indices [i-period+1 ... i].
168 for j in range(self.period):
169 idx = i - j
170 sum_returns += log_returns[idx]
171
172 mean = sum_returns / self.period
173
174 # B. Calculate Variance (Sum of Squared Deviations)
175 sum_sq_diff = 0.0
176 for j in range(self.period):
177 idx = i - j
178 diff = log_returns[idx] - mean
179 sum_sq_diff += diff * diff
180
181 # -------------------------------------------------------------
182 # Logic Step 3.3: Compute Sample Standard Deviation
183 #
184 # [Formula]
185 # StdDev = Sqrt( SumSq / (N - 1) )
186 # We use N-1 (Bessel's correction) for sample data.
187 # -------------------------------------------------------------
188 std_dev = math.sqrt(sum_sq_diff / (self.period - 1))
189
190 # -------------------------------------------------------------
191 # Logic Step 3.4: Annualize
192 # -------------------------------------------------------------
193 hv = std_dev * annual_factor
194
195 self.values.append(hv)
196​
197​
198# =============================================================================
199# Functional Wrapper (Procedural Interface)
200# =============================================================================
201def calculate(candles, period=20):
202 """
203 Computes Historical Volatility (Annualized).
204 """
205 # 1. Instantiation
206 instance = HistoricalVolatility(period)
207
208 # 2. Execution
209 instance.calculate(candles)
210
211 # 3. Extraction
212 return instance.values
